To provide guidance and support to all medical staff performing 12 Lead Electrocardiograms within Mid Essex Hospitals NHS Trust, to ensure that they are performed in line with The Society of Cardiological Science and Technology (SCST) recommended guidelines, ensuring consistency and continuity between recordings taken and comparatively across all departments within the trust.

By providing clinical guidance, staff will have access to and be provided with appropriate training. This will allow all suitable medical staff trust wide to correctly perform and record a 12 Lead Electrocardiogram, reducing the number of recording errors and increasing consistency across the trust as a whole.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 2)

A  Lead Electrocardiogram (ECG) is a non-invasive procedure used to obtain information about the electrophysiology of the heart, including the heart rate and rhythm. It is a representation of the heart's electrical activity during depolarisation and repolarisation recorded from electrodes placed on the body's surface, that enable pathology to be localised to particular regions of the heart.
Electrocardiography is still regarded as a gold standard investigation and is often the first diagnostic test performed in people with suspected heart or conduction tissue disease.

The portability, low cost and ease of operation means that ECG's can be recorded quickly and easily by a wide variety of medical personnel in a number of clinical locations, including within and outside the hospital setting.
This clinical guidance applies to any medical professional performing and recording 12 Lead Electrocardiograms on Adults (patients aged  Years or above).
The interpretation of the recording should only be completed by medical professionals deemed suitably qualified to do so, such as Doctors, Cardiac Physiologists, and Senior Nursing Staff.
All medical staff are responsible for:
Being aware and compliant with this clinical guidance.
Ensuring they have adequate and appropriate training before performance of a 12 Lead Electrocardiogram.
Ensuring they are competent in the use of the appropriate electrocardiography equipment and have completed competencies that document so: CS-036-001-13 (Refer to Appendix 1 for Core Competency).
Ensuring that adequate information about the test is relayed to the patient and/or relative and verbal consent is gained prior to commencement of the 12 Lead ECG Recording.
Liaising with other members of the medical team if deemed appropriate regarding the results of the recording.
Training responsibility will remain with individual staff members and overall responsibility for wards/clinical areas with the Ward or Department Manager.
Compliance will be audited through training records in line with local trust learning and development policies and CPD records.

All staff will adhere to Trust guidelines on infection prevention at all times whilst performing a 12 Lead Electrocardiogram, such as hand washing, the use of additional infection prevention measures when required i.e.: gloves and aprons and effective decontamination of all non-disposable equipment between patients.

Ensure the area is private and quiet to allow for privacy and dignity to be maintained at all times where reasonably possible, for example using a separate room, ensuring that curtains/screens are pulled.
Ensure that the area is accessible for both able bodied patients and staff and also the disabled.
Ensure that where reasonably possible those patients with Learning Difficulties are seen promptly to avoid excessive long waits that may cause distress or anxiety.

Ensure where reasonably possible adjustments are made to the environment to ensure that hypersensitivities and sensory overload is accounted for those patients with Autism, for example providing a quiet area, ensuring that the work space is tidy and organised, turning off interior lighting (if necessary), allowing the presence of a transitional object to provide familiarity.
(Refer to ‘Caring for a young person /adult with autism in the acute setting'; register number 14010)

In patients identified as having a Learning Disability efforts should be made to seek the patient's Hospital Passport in advance where possible to assess the need for additional support. If this is unavailable or not conceivable, as much background information should be gained from the patient and/or their carers as possible. (Please refer to ‘Caring for Adult Patients with a Learning Disability in the Acute Hospital'; register number 09116).
Confirm familiarity with and competence of the type of ECG Machine to be used.
Check that the ECG Machine is safe for use with no cable fractures or faults. (If the machine is deemed unsafe, do not use, remove from service and contact BME).
Check that the machine has sufficient paper to make a suitable recording.
Ensure the calibration is set as standard (set by BME).
Check the time and date settings are accurate, if not refer to the specific ECG.
Machine instruction manual if available or contact BME as soon as possible to rectify.

Staff should introduce themselves to the patient, their role and briefly describe the procedure for recording an ECG. This should cover the level of undress involved, the use of adhesive electrodes and reassurance that the procedure is brief and painless.

In those patients identified as having learning difficulties or autism, staff should ensure that they used a person centred approach, speak slowly and clearly, ensure that they are mindful of the language used as autistic patients often take everything at literal value, and communicate at a level at which the patient can understand. If required and appropriate allow the patient's relative or carer to assist to try and minimise distress for the patient.
If the patient is unable to undress independently provide them with suitable and appropriate assistance where required.
If appropriate and requested the patient should always be allowed to have a chaperone present, this can include a relative or carer if the patient so wishes.
Verbal consent should be gained from the patient to proceed with the recording. If the recording is in small children, consent will need to be obtained from a parent or guardian.

Confirm the identity of the patient by checking their name and date of birth. If the patient is unable to provide confirmation of their own identifying details confirmation should be sought from the hospital identification wristband or medical documentation.
In some cases confirmation may be also be sought from relative or carers, such as in the case of small children.
Ask the patient to undress from above the waist to allow access to the upper torso for accurate electrode placement. This includes the removal of bras in female patients.
Patients must be allowed to undress in a private area with minimal interruption where possible.

Ensure that the patient comfortable, with their head and neck supported by a pillow and is lying flat or in a semi recumbent position of approximately 45° with their arms and legs relaxed by their sides.

Where this is not possible any variation should be marked on the ECG Recording, for example in patients that are wheelchair bound and unable to transfer onto the couch, the test may be performed with them remaining in the wheelchair as long as the recording is annotated to identify so. This is the responsibility of the member of staff who is making the recording.
Skin Preparation
Skin preparation is often required in order to produce the most accurate and artefact free ECG recording by minimising the skin to electrode impedance.
Care should be taken especially in patients with delicate, sensitive or broken skin, such as children or the elderly.
If appropriate, exfoliation may be performed using very light abrasion with a proprietary abrasive tape, paper towel or gauze.

Chest hair should where possible be removed to ensure the electrodes have adequate contact with the skin. Verbal consent must always be gained from the patient before doing so and this should be done using a suitable razor which will be disposed of in a sharps bin immediately after use.

In patients identified as having Learning Difficulties or Autism ensure that they are informed where and why you need to touch them during the procedure, especially when you are about to touch them with medical equipment as metal, plastic and other objects of different temperatures can feel unusual to those with autism especially in those with tactile sensitivity as they can find it difficult to tolerate ECG electrodes.
Electrode Placement
Electrodes should be positioned in accordance with the AHA/SCST recommendations.

If any electrodes need to be sited in non-standard positions, the recording must be labelled appropriately with this information to avoid misinterpretation by suitable qualified medical professionals if alterations to the ECG waveforms have occurred as a result.
Limb Electrodes

Limb Electrodes should be placed on the wrists and ankles whenever possible. Moving the electrodes up the limbs can alter the appearance of the ECG and should be avoided unless there is a significant tremor such as in those who suffer with Parkinson's disease or in those where limb amputation has taken place.

In patients who have had full or partial amputation of any limb the electrode should be placed on the most distal part of the limb, for example in a below the knee leg amputation the electrode should be placed on the end of the remaining limb stump. If the whole limb has been amputated, placement of the limb electrode on the lower hip is accepted.

Placing limb electrodes on the torso is not acceptable as this has been noted to significantly alter the waveforms and can invalidate the recording for diagnostic use. Any adaptations from standard SCST recommendations should be marked on the ECG Recording. This is the responsibility of the member of staff who is making the recording.
Chest Leads
The correct anatomical positions for the chest leads have been defined and should always be used unless access is not possible (Illustrated in the Diagrams below).
The centre of the active area of the electrode should be aligned with the relevant anatomical landmark.
Technique for Locating Chest Electrode Positions

Locate the Angle of Louis (the junction of the sternum and manubrium) by running a finger down the sternum from the top until a bony horizontal ridge in located. Move the finger along the ridge and down, and to the right will locate the 2nd intercostal space.
From the 2nd Intercostal space count down until the th intercostal space is reached, move the fingers in until the edge of the strum can be felt and place electrode V1 in this position.
Repeat this process on the left side to correctly position electrode V2.

Rib spaces may be offset, especially in patient who have had previous cardiac or chest surgery, and therefore electrode spacing needs to be accurately counted on both the right and left of the sternum and not assumed that V2 should be in alignment with V1.
V4 electrode should be placed in the th intercostal space in the mid clavicular line (the mid-point of the clavicle).

To locate this place the little finger on the end of the clavicle that aligns with the shoulder and the thumb on the clavicle end at the base of the throat. Without overstretching the fingers the mid clavicular line should fall approximately where the middle finger falls.
Bring the hand down the torso until the th intercostal space is located and place electrode V4 in this position.
V3 electrode should then be placed mid-way between V2 and V4.
Electrodes V5 and V6 should then be positioned in horizontal alignment with the V4 Electrode.
V5 should be placed on the anterior axillary line (usually this falls in line with the crease of the armpit).
V6 should be placed in the mid axillary line (usually this falls in line with the mid-point of the armpit).

In Female patients where the anatomical locations may be covered by breast tissue it is conventional to place the V4 electrode beneath the left breast in the mid clavicular line and also V5 and V6 beneath the breast tissue if required.
Technique for Locating Posterior Chest Electrode Positions (V7, V8, V9)
In some clinical situation it may be necessary to perform a 12 Lead ECG using posterior electrode positions, in the absence of an ECG Machine capable of recording a  Lead ECG.
Posterior electrode positions are placed in the same transverse plane as V4.
Chest electrodes V1-V3 remain located as for a standard 12 Lead ECG.

In the absence of an ECG Machine capable of recording a 15 Lead ECG, it is recommended that a standard 12 Lead ECG be recorded first, and then subsequently chest electrodes V4, V5 and V6 should be repositioned into the posterior chest electrode positions (V7, V8 and V9).
A second recording should be made showing the posterior lead positions. (V7, V8, V9)
The second ECG recording should be clearly annotated with the new chest lead positions. See below for an example:
Recording a 12 Lead Electrocardiogram (ECG) Trace
Enter the patient identifiable data such as name, date of birth, hospital number into the ECG machine.
Ensure that the name of the member of staff recording the trace is also input and the location at which the tracing is being recorded e.g.: A210, A&E, A305 etc.
Attach the lead wires to the correct electrodes, often these will be colour coded and labelled to assist.
Ensure the patient is relaxed and remains as still as possible.
Record an ECG.
Check the tracing for quality to ensure that this is the most accurate recording obtainable.
If the patient is likely to need Serial ECG's in a short space of time the electrodes are able to remain in place to allow accurate comparison, from example in the case of a

patient during a myocardial infarction. Otherwise all electrodes are single use only and should be removed from the patient after the recording has been made. Leaving electrodes unnecessarily stuck to a patient can risk damage to the skin.
Once a satisfactory recording is obtained if applicable removed the lead wires and electrodes from the patient.
Dispose of the electrodes in line with trust infection prevention guidelines and decontaminate equipment appropriately prior to its use on another patient.
Wash hands according to the ‘Hand Hygiene Policy'; register number 14072.
Ensure that the ECG recording gets given to the appropriate medical professional for interpretation or fixed inside the patient's hospital notes to avoid the recording being misplaced.
Technique for Locating Right Sided Chest Electrode Positions (V3R, V4R, V5R, V6R) – Including Dextrocardia/Situs Inversus
In some clinical situations it may be necessary to perform a 12 Lead ECG using right sided electrode positions such as in those patients with Dextrocardia or Situs Inversus.

Dextrocardia is a clinical condition in which the heart is located on the right hand side of the chest rather than the left. This may be manifested as true dextrocardia in which only the heart is located on the right side or Situs Inversus, a congenital condition in which the major visceral organs are reversed or mirrored from their normal positions on the left.
Dextrocardia may be suspected if a resting 12 Lead ECG reveals the following characteristics:
Negative P Waves;
Negative QRS Complexes in Lead I (ensuring technical errors such as Right and Left Arm Limb Lead Reversal have been fully excluded);
Poor R Wave progression in V1-V6.

If Dextrocardia is suspected a normal 12 Lead ECG should be performed first and then a second ECG should be recorded with the chest electrodes (V3-V6) positioned on the right hand side of the chest using the same intercostal spacing and anatomic landmarks as for a standard 12 Lead ECG.
**V1 and V2 should remain in their usual locations**
The second right sided ECG should be clearly annotated to describe the repositioned electrodes (V3R, V4R, V5R, and V6R).
Performing 12 Lead ECG's in the Emergency Situation (ECG)

Where reasonably possible and within the constraints of the situation all 12 Lead Electrocardiograms should be performed to SCST Standard. Any adaptations from standard SCST recommendations should be marked on the ECG Recording. This is the responsibility of the member of staff who is making the recording.

In those likely to need Serial ECG's over a relatively short time period, for example in a myocardial infarction, the ECG electrodes can remain in place until no longer adhesive and ensuring no residue or irritation to the skin.
However caution should be taken when performing Serial ECG's to ensure that the electrodes are in comparable positions and have not migrated from the original placements.
Breach Reporting
In the event that this guidance is not followed and as a result the patient suffers harm, a Datix should be completed.
Audit and Monitoring
Training will be audited through training records in line with local trust learning and development policies and CPD records.
Adherence to this guidance will be monitored by review of reported incidents and complaints via the Datix system. These will be dealt with by the relevant head of department/ward.
References

Emergency Nurses Association (September 2013) ‘Right Sided and Posterior Electrocardiograms (ECG's)' [Online] Available at: https://www.loyolamedicine.org/sites/default/files/gme/internal- medicine/rightsideecg_0.pdf

Nottingham University Hospitals NHS Trust (September 2012) ‘Guidelines for Recording an Electrocardiogram' [Online] Available at: https://www.nottingham.ac.uk/mhs/documents/clinical-skills/nuh- guidelines/electrocardiogram.pdf
Royal Wolverhampton NHS Trust (January 2018) ‘How to Perform a 12 Lead ECG' [Online] Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tuZn65Xet9Q

Society of Cardiological Science and Technology (SCST) (July 2014), ‘Clinical Guidelines by Conseus ‘Recording a Standard  Lead Electrocardiogram' An approved methodology by the Society of Cardiological Science and Technology' [Online] Available at: http://www.scst.org.uk/resources/CAC_SCST_Recording_a_12- lead_ECG_final_version_2014_CS2v2.0.pdf
Appendix 1
MEDICAL DEVICE / EQUIPMENT COMPETENCY SELF ASSESSMENT STATEMENT

table_items.text: Areas where equipment used: All clinical areas using this equipment
Complex Intermediate Basic External / DCCT Super-user Self/ Peer

data.text: The statements below are designed to assess your competence to use this device. You should self-assess your competency after you have received the relevant training. Responsibility for use of the equipment remains with you, so if you are in any doubt about your competence to use the device, you must seek additional training in liaison with your line manager / supervisor and then re-assess your competence against the statement. Sources of training support  include  the  product  operating  manual  and  training  from  peers,  super-users  or  Clinical  Technicians  as appropriate.

table_items.text: Questions to ask yourself: Are you safe using this equipment? Do you know the following?
Understand, and are competent in, positioning ECG leads?
Retrieve and print a previous reading?
Able to change and delete data?
Clean/decontaminate and safely store this equipment?
Does the recorder have battery back up?

data.text: You must be able to answer yes to all questions relevant to your role to consider yourself competent. If you are competent, you should date and sign your  Diagnostic & Therapeutic Equipment Competency Record for this equipment. If you are not competent, please identify this on your record, signing and dating the record appropriately, and discuss with your manager how and when your training needs will be met.
Your line manager should retain your Diagnostic & Therapeutic Equipment Competency Record. Self - assessment is undertaken on a one-off basis but will be reviewed annually at appraisal.
Author: Chris Brown/P Ruddock  Created on: 25/07/2013
